notesStmt.note: Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

supportDesc.extent: 121 folios (+3 unfoliated flyleaves at the beginning and at the end).

collation.p: 10 quires, signature in Hebrew characters at the end of quires (signatures are continuous in the throughout the four volumes, volume 3: quires 21-30). Quires are of 12 leaves each, apart from the first quire which has now 14 leaves and the last one which has 11 leaves. Several unfoliated paper flyleaves (of Christian provenance, with watermark of two lions holding a banner) at the beginning and at the end.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Sefardi square script, punctuated through the main text and unpunctuated through the masoretic notes, of the 14th century.

decoDesc.decoNote: Masorah in micrographical form in some places. Initial words of the books are unfinished.

binding.p: Post-1600 Harleian binding, red leather with gold tooling, marble paper pastedown. Spine: 'Bible III. Hebrew. Brit. Mus. Harl. Ms. 5498.'

history.provenance: Acquisition: Inscription by Edward Harley's librarian, Humfrey Wanley, 28 July 1725. The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts. Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta, née Cavendish Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d.1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
